topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.0: Non-KVM Region Overview

titlealts.searchtitle: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade: HP Helion OpenStack Overview

body.p: For installation and maintenance, HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade consists of three logical or conceptual regions: Non-KVM, KVM, and the optional baremetal.

A server in the Non-KVM region hosts the lifecycle manager, which contains the installation scripts and configuration files to deploy and maintain HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade; and HP Helion OpenStack, a commercial-grade distribution of OpenStack.
Note: These regions do not function as OpenStack regions.
body.section:
Lifecycle ManagerAll four deployment models install the lifecycle manager into the non-KVM region.
The Non-KVM environment includes a full installation of a lifecycle manager, an application that is used to deploy HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade and can be used for ongoing operations and maintenance of the system.
Physical Node Preparation. The lifecycle manager can configure nodes prior to installation of a base operating system, including node discovery/inventory, BIOS configuration, (specifically setting PXE boot on primary interface), GRUB settings, RAID setup for local disks, iLO/IPMI set up and firmware upgrades.
OS Install. The lifecycle manager takes a PXE bootable node and installs a base operating system.
Cloud Configuration. The lifecycle manager can provide detailed information about the cloud topology, such as the structure of control plane, assignment of services to nodes, and service configuration. You can also specify environment-specific configurations.
OS Configuration. The lifecycle manager can automatically execute operating system configuration values, such as NIC assignments, NTP settings, DNS settings, NIC bonding, sysctl settings, VLAN creation and so forth. The lifecycle manager uses the Ansible data model output and server playbooks to automatically apply the per-node configurations.
Helion Operation & Maintenance. The lifecycle manager is responsible for the deploy, upgrade and maintenance lifecycle of the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade system.

section.title: HP Helion OpenStack
section.p: All four deployment models install HP Helion OpenStack into the non-KVM region.

HPE Helion OpenStack2.0 is the latest OpenStack-based infrastructure-as-a-service cloud platform release from HP. It is based on the OpenStack Kilo release and implements core services and features of Kilo while providing new installation and management features.

HP Helion OpenStack offers many services based on the different OpenStack projects to provide the functionality you need. Visit the HP Helion OpenStack Services Overview page for a complete list of services.

section.title: HP Distributed Cloud Networking (DCN)
section.p: The Tahoe, Memphis, and Sacramento deployment models include HP DCN.

The optional HP DCN is a software-Defined Networking (SDN) solution that enhances data center (DC) network virtualization by automatically establishing connectivity between compute resources upon their creation.
Refer to the HP DCN documentation for more information, system requirements and installation instructions.

In general, the main components in the HP DCN solution are: Virtualized Services Directory (VSD) and Virtualized Services Directory Architect (VSD Architect), Virtualized Services Controller (VSC) and Virtual Routing and Switching (VRS).
Virtualized Services Directory (VSD). The HP VSD is a programmable policy and analytics engine. The VSD runs as a number of processes in a virtual machine (VM) environment.
Virtualized Services Directory Architect (VSD Architect). The VSD Architect is a GUI for management tasks on the VSD.
Virtualized Services Controller (VSC). The HP VSC is a powerful SDN controller. It functions as the robust network control plane for DCs, maintaining a full view of per-tenant network and service topologies. The VSC runs in a virtual machine environment.
Virtual Routing and Switching (VRS). The HP VRS component is an enhanced Open vSwitch (OVS) implementation that constitutes the network forwarding plane.
For lower bandwidth needs, the software-based Virtual Routing Services Gateway(VRS-G) can be run in a dedicated bare-metal server or as a virtual machine, allowing the incorporation of bare-metal assets as virtualized extensions of the data center, as well as providing an exit gateway for the DVRS’ overlay, floating-IP and shared-services traffic.

body.section:
ESX IntegrationThe Memphis, and Sacramento deployment models include VMWare ESX.
HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade optionally supports VMWare ESX hypervisor using HPE Distributed Cloud Networking (aka DCN). With our ESX integration, the cloud can provision and manage an ESX cluster. VMWare Compute Proxy is used as a part of ESX integration. The VMware vCenter driver connects to ESX clusters through Nova Compute proxy nodes. A Compute node scheduler sees each cluster as compute and uses the same for scheduling new instances.
Refer to the VMWare documentation for more information, system requirements and installation instructions.
DCN/ESX Integration
This DCN/ESX integration uses the VRSvAPP application to connect the VMware vCenter™ networking to the Network Operations controller to manage workload networks. The ESX integration uses the OVSvApp application to connect the vCenter networking to the Network Operations controller to manage workload networks. HP DCN handles virtual networking between HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade and the ESX servers.
Together, HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade, ESX, and DCN combine to provide the best features from OpenStack, ESX and DCN, including:
Support for inter-region and inter-cloud communication between different data centers.
OpenStack features with rich services such as Keystone, Glance, Nova, Neutron, Cinder, Horizon
ESX provides foundation for building and managing a virtualized IT infrastructure
ESX provides reliability and performance
ESX hypervisors abstract processor, memory and storage
DCN provides programmable business logic and a powerful policy engine
DCN provides an open and highly responsive solution that scales and spans across multi-tenant DCs
ESX region uses a VMDK driver to offer multi-backend storage support from Cinder
